29.13: Take all the fat around the internal organs, the long lobe of the liver, and the two kidneys and the fat around them, and burn it all on the altar.
29.14: Then take the rest of the bull, including its hide, meat, and dung, and burn it outside the camp as a sin offering.
29.15: “Next Aaron and his sons must lay their hands on the head of one of the rams.
29.16: Then slaughter the ram, and splatter its blood against all sides of the altar.
29.17: Cut the ram into pieces, and wash off the internal organs and the legs. Set them alongside the head and the other pieces of the body,
29.18: then burn the entire animal on the altar. This is a burnt offering to the LORD; it is a pleasing aroma, a special gift presented to the LORD.
29.19: “Now take the other ram, and have Aaron and his sons lay their hands on its head.
29.20: Then slaughter it, and apply some of its blood to the right earlobes of Aaron and his sons. Also put it on the thumbs of their right hands and the big toes of their right feet. Splatter the rest of the blood against all sides of the altar.
29.21: Then take some of the blood from the altar and some of the anointing oil, and sprinkle it on Aaron and his sons and on their garments. In this way, they and their garments will be set apart as holy.
29.22: “Since this is the ram for the ordination of Aaron and his sons, take the fat of the ram, including the fat of the broad tail, the fat around the internal organs, the long lobe of the liver, and the two kidneys and the fat around them, along with the right thigh.
29.23: Then take one round loaf of bread, one thin cake mixed with olive oil, and one wafer from the basket of bread without yeast that was placed in the LORD’s presence.
29.24: Put all these in the hands of Aaron and his sons to be lifted up as a special offering to the LORD.
29.25: Afterward take the various breads from their hands, and burn them on the altar along with the burnt offering. It is a pleasing aroma to the LORD, a special gift for him.
29.26: Then take the breast of Aaron’s ordination ram, and lift it up in the LORD’s presence as a special offering to him. Then keep it as your own portion.
29.27: “Set aside the portions of the ordination ram that belong to Aaron and his sons. This includes the breast and the thigh that were lifted up before the LORD as a special offering.
29.28: In the future, whenever the people of Israel lift up a peace offering, a portion of it must be set aside for Aaron and his descendants. This is their permanent right, and it is a sacred offering from the Israelites to the LORD.
29.29: “Aaron’s sacred garments must be preserved for his descendants who succeed him, and they will wear them when they are anointed and ordained.
29.30: The descendant who succeeds him as high priest will wear these clothes for seven days as he ministers in the Tabernacle and the Holy Place.
29.31: “Take the ram used in the ordination ceremony, and boil its meat in a sacred place.
29.32: Then Aaron and his sons will eat this meat, along with the bread in the basket, at the Tabernacle entrance.
29.33: They alone may eat the meat and bread used for their purification in the ordination ceremony. No one else may eat them, for these things are set apart and holy.
29.34: If any of the ordination meat or bread remains until the morning, it must be burned. It may not be eaten, for it is holy.
29.35: “This is how you will ordain Aaron and his sons to their offices, just as I have commanded you. The ordination ceremony will go on for seven days.
29.36: Each day you must sacrifice a young bull as a sin offering to purify them, making them right with the LORD. Afterward, cleanse the altar by purifying it; make it holy by anointing it with oil.
29.37: Purify the altar, and consecrate it every day for seven days. After that, the altar will be absolutely holy, and whatever touches it will become holy.
29.38: “These are the sacrifices you are to offer regularly on the altar. Each day, offer two lambs that are a year old,
29.39: one in the morning and the other in the evening.
29.40: With one of them, offer two quarts of choice flour mixed with one quart of pure oil of pressed olives; also, offer one quart of wine as a liquid offering.
29.41: Offer the other lamb in the evening, along with the same offerings of flour and wine as in the morning. It will be a pleasing aroma, a special gift presented to the LORD.
29.42: “These burnt offerings are to be made each day from generation to generation. Offer them in the LORD’s presence at the Tabernacle entrance; there I will meet with you and speak with you.
29.43: I will meet the people of Israel there, in the place made holy by my glorious presence.
29.44: Yes, I will consecrate the Tabernacle and the altar, and I will consecrate Aaron and his sons to serve me as priests.
29.45: Then I will live among the people of Israel and be their God,
29.46: and they will know that I am the LORD their God. I am the one who brought them out of the land of Egypt so that I could live among them. I am the LORD their God.

30.1: “Then make another altar of acacia wood for burning incense.
30.2: Make it 18 inches square and 36 inches high, with horns at the corners carved from the same piece of wood as the altar itself.
30.3: Overlay the top, sides, and horns of the altar with pure gold, and run a gold molding around the entire altar.
30.4: Make two gold rings, and attach them on opposite sides of the altar below the gold molding to hold the carrying poles.
30.5: Make the poles of acacia wood and overlay them with gold.
30.6: Place the incense altar just outside the inner curtain that shields the Ark of the Covenant, in front of the Ark’s cover—the place of atonement—that covers the tablets inscribed with the terms of the covenant. I will meet with you there.
30.7: “Every morning when Aaron maintains the lamps, he must burn fragrant incense on the altar.
30.8: And each evening when he lights the lamps, he must again burn incense in the LORD’s presence. This must be done from generation to generation.
30.9: Do not offer any unholy incense on this altar, or any burnt offerings, grain offerings, or liquid offerings.
30.10: “Once a year Aaron must purify the altar by smearing its horns with blood from the offering made to purify the people from their sin. This will be a regular, annual event from generation to generation, for this is the LORD’s most holy altar.”
30.11: Then the LORD said to Moses,
30.12: “Whenever you take a census of the people of Israel, each man who is counted must pay a ransom for himself to the LORD. Then no plague will strike the people as you count them.
30.13: Each person who is counted must give a small piece of silver as a sacred offering to the LORD. (This payment is half a shekel, based on the sanctuary shekel, which equals twenty gerahs.)
30.14: All who have reached their twentieth birthday must give this sacred offering to the LORD.
30.15: When this offering is given to the LORD to purify your lives, making you right with him, the rich must not give more than the specified amount, and the poor must not give less.
30.16: Receive this ransom money from the Israelites, and use it for the care of the Tabernacle. It will bring the Israelites to the LORD’s attention, and it will purify your lives.”
30.17: Then the LORD said to Moses,
30.18: “Make a bronze washbasin with a bronze stand. Place it between the Tabernacle and the altar, and fill it with water.
30.19: Aaron and his sons will wash their hands and feet there.
30.20: They must wash with water whenever they go into the Tabernacle to appear before the LORD and when they approach the altar to burn up their special gifts to the LORD—or they will die!
30.21: They must always wash their hands and feet, or they will die. This is a permanent law for Aaron and his descendants, to be observed from generation to generation.”
30.22: Then the LORD said to Moses,
30.23: “Collect choice spices—12 1 / 2 pounds of pure myrrh, 6 1 / 4 pounds of fragrant cinnamon, 6 1 / 4 pounds of fragrant calamus,
30.24: and 12 1 / 2 pounds of cassia—as measured by the weight of the sanctuary shekel. Also get one gallon of olive oil.
30.25: Like a skilled incense maker, blend these ingredients to make a holy anointing oil.
30.26: Use this sacred oil to anoint the Tabernacle, the Ark of the Covenant,
30.27: the table and all its utensils, the lampstand and all its accessories, the incense altar,
30.28: the altar of burnt offering and all its utensils, and the washbasin with its stand.
30.29: Consecrate them to make them absolutely holy. After this, whatever touches them will also become holy.
30.30: “Anoint Aaron and his sons also, consecrating them to serve me as priests.
30.31: And say to the people of Israel, ‘This holy anointing oil is reserved for me from generation to generation.
30.32: It must never be used to anoint anyone else, and you must never make any blend like it for yourselves. It is holy, and you must treat it as holy.
30.33: Anyone who makes a blend like it or anoints someone other than a priest will be cut off from the community.’”
30.34: Then the LORD said to Moses, “Gather fragrant spices—resin droplets, mollusk shell, and galbanum—and mix these fragrant spices with pure frankincense, weighed out in equal amounts.
30.35: Using the usual techniques of the incense maker, blend the spices together and sprinkle them with salt to produce a pure and holy incense.
30.36: Grind some of the mixture into a very fine powder and put it in front of the Ark of the Covenant, where I will meet with you in the Tabernacle. You must treat this incense as most holy.
30.37: Never use this formula to make this incense for yourselves. It is reserved for the LORD, and you must treat it as holy.
30.38: Anyone who makes incense like this for personal use will be cut off from the community.”

31.1: Then the LORD said to Moses,
31.2: “Look, I have specifically chosen Bezalel son of Uri, grandson of Hur, of the tribe of Judah.
31.3: I have filled him with the Spirit of God, giving him great wisdom, ability, and expertise in all kinds of crafts.
31.4: He is a master craftsman, expert in working with gold, silver, and bronze.
31.5: He is skilled in engraving and mounting gemstones and in carving wood. He is a master at every craft!
31.6: “And I have personally appointed Oholiab son of Ahisamach, of the tribe of Dan, to be his assistant. Moreover, I have given special skill to all the gifted craftsmen so they can make all the things I have commanded you to make:
31.7: the Tabernacle; the Ark of the Covenant; the Ark’s cover—the place of atonement; all the furnishings of the Tabernacle;
31.8: the table and its utensils; the pure gold lampstand with all its accessories; the incense altar;
31.9: the altar of burnt offering with all its utensils; the washbasin with its stand;
31.10: the beautifully stitched garments—the sacred garments for Aaron the priest, and the garments for his sons to wear as they minister as priests;
31.11: the anointing oil; the fragrant incense for the Holy Place. The craftsmen must make everything as I have commanded you.”
31.12: The LORD then gave these instructions to Moses:
31.13: “Tell the people of Israel: ‘Be careful to keep my Sabbath day, for the Sabbath is a sign of the covenant between me and you from generation to generation. It is given so you may know that I am the LORD, who makes you holy.
31.14: You must keep the Sabbath day, for it is a holy day for you. Anyone who desecrates it must be put to death; anyone who works on that day will be cut off from the community.
31.15: You have six days each week for your ordinary work, but the seventh day must be a Sabbath day of complete rest, a holy day dedicated to the LORD. Anyone who works on the Sabbath must be put to death.
31.16: The people of Israel must keep the Sabbath day by observing it from generation to generation. This is a covenant obligation for all time.
31.17: It is a permanent sign of my covenant with the people of Israel. For in six days the LORD made heaven and earth, but on the seventh day he stopped working and was refreshed.’”
31.18: When the LORD finished speaking with Moses on Mount Sinai, he gave him the two stone tablets inscribed with the terms of the covenant, written by the finger of God.

32.1: When the people saw how long it was taking Moses to come back down the mountain, they gathered around Aaron. “Come on,” they said, “make us some gods who can lead us. We don’t know what happened to this fellow Moses, who brought us here from the land of Egypt.”
32.2: So Aaron said, “Take the gold rings from the ears of your wives and sons and daughters, and bring them to me.”
32.3: All the people took the gold rings from their ears and brought them to Aaron.
32.4: Then Aaron took the gold, melted it down, and molded it into the shape of a calf. When the people saw it, they exclaimed, “O Israel, these are the gods who brought you out of the land of Egypt!”
32.5: Aaron saw how excited the people were, so he built an altar in front of the calf. Then he announced, “Tomorrow will be a festival to the LORD!”
32.6: The people got up early the next morning to sacrifice burnt offerings and peace offerings. After this, they celebrated with feasting and drinking, and they indulged in pagan revelry.
32.7: The LORD told Moses, “Quick! Go down the mountain! Your people whom you brought from the land of Egypt have corrupted themselves.
32.8: How quickly they have turned away from the way I commanded them to live! They have melted down gold and made a calf, and they have bowed down and sacrificed to it. They are saying, ‘These are your gods, O Israel, who brought you out of the land of Egypt.’”
32.9: Then the LORD said, “I have seen how stubborn and rebellious these people are.
32.10: Now leave me alone so my fierce anger can blaze against them, and I will destroy them. Then I will make you, Moses, into a great nation.”
32.11: But Moses tried to pacify the LORD his God. “O LORD!” he said. “Why are you so angry with your own people whom you brought from the land of Egypt with such great power and such a strong hand?
32.12: Why let the Egyptians say, ‘Their God rescued them with the evil intention of slaughtering them in the mountains and wiping them from the face of the earth’? Turn away from your fierce anger. Change your mind about this terrible disaster you have threatened against your people!
32.13: Remember your servants Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. You bound yourself with an oath to them, saying, ‘I will make your descendants as numerous as the stars of heaven. And I will give them all of this land that I have promised to your descendants, and they will possess it forever.’”
32.14: So the LORD changed his mind about the terrible disaster he had threatened to bring on his people.
32.15: Then Moses turned and went down the mountain. He held in his hands the two stone tablets inscribed with the terms of the covenant. They were inscribed on both sides, front and back.
32.16: These tablets were God’s work; the words on them were written by God himself.
32.17: When Joshua heard the boisterous noise of the people shouting below them, he exclaimed to Moses, “It sounds like war in the camp!”
32.18: But Moses replied, “No, it’s not a shout of victory nor the wailing of defeat. I hear the sound of a celebration.”
32.19: When they came near the camp, Moses saw the calf and the dancing, and he burned with anger. He threw the stone tablets to the ground, smashing them at the foot of the mountain.
32.20: He took the calf they had made and burned it. Then he ground it into powder, threw it into the water, and forced the people to drink it.
32.21: Finally, he turned to Aaron and demanded, “What did these people do to you to make you bring such terrible sin upon them?”
32.22: “Don’t get so upset, my lord,” Aaron replied. “You yourself know how evil these people are.
32.23: They said to me, ‘Make us gods who will lead us. We don’t know what happened to this fellow Moses, who brought us here from the land of Egypt.’
32.24: So I told them, ‘Whoever has gold jewelry, take it off.’ When they brought it to me, I simply threw it into the fire—and out came this calf!”
32.25: Moses saw that Aaron had let the people get completely out of control, much to the amusement of their enemies.
32.26: So he stood at the entrance to the camp and shouted, “All of you who are on the LORD’s side, come here and join me.” And all the Levites gathered around him.
32.27: Moses told them, “This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: Each of you, take your swords and go back and forth from one end of the camp to the other. Kill everyone—even your brothers, friends, and neighbors.”
32.28: The Levites obeyed Moses’ command, and about 3,000 people died that day.
32.29: Then Moses told the Levites, “Today you have ordained yourselves for the service of the LORD, for you obeyed him even though it meant killing your own sons and brothers. Today you have earned a blessing.”
32.30: The next day Moses said to the people, “You have committed a terrible sin, but I will go back up to the LORD on the mountain. Perhaps I will be able to obtain forgiveness for your sin.”
32.31: So Moses returned to the LORD and said, “Oh, what a terrible sin these people have committed. They have made gods of gold for themselves.
32.32: But now, if you will only forgive their sin—but if not, erase my name from the record you have written!”
32.33: But the LORD replied to Moses, “No, I will erase the name of everyone who has sinned against me.
32.34: Now go, lead the people to the place I told you about. Look! My angel will lead the way before you. And when I come to call the people to account, I will certainly hold them responsible for their sins.”
32.35: Then the LORD sent a great plague upon the people because they had worshiped the calf Aaron had made.

33.1: The LORD said to Moses, “Get going, you and the people you brought up from the land of Egypt. Go up to the land I swore to give to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. I told them, ‘I will give this land to your descendants.’
33.2: And I will send an angel before you to drive out the Canaanites, Amorites, Hittites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites.
33.3: Go up to this land that flows with milk and honey. But I will not travel among you, for you are a stubborn and rebellious people. If I did, I would surely destroy you along the way.”
33.4: When the people heard these stern words, they went into mourning and stopped wearing their jewelry and fine clothes.
33.5: For the LORD had told Moses to tell them, “You are a stubborn and rebellious people. If I were to travel with you for even a moment, I would destroy you. Remove your jewelry and fine clothes while I decide what to do with you.”
33.6: So from the time they left Mount Sinai, the Israelites wore no more jewelry or fine clothes.
33.7: It was Moses’ practice to take the Tent of Meeting and set it up some distance from the camp. Everyone who wanted to make a request of the LORD would go to the Tent of Meeting outside the camp.
33.8: Whenever Moses went out to the Tent of Meeting, all the people would get up and stand in the entrances of their own tents. They would all watch Moses until he disappeared inside.
33.9: As he went into the tent, the pillar of cloud would come down and hover at its entrance while the LORD spoke with Moses.
33.10: When the people saw the cloud standing at the entrance of the tent, they would stand and bow down in front of their own tents.
33.11: Inside the Tent of Meeting, the LORD would speak to Moses face to face, as one speaks to a friend. Afterward Moses would return to the camp, but the young man who assisted him, Joshua son of Nun, would remain behind in the Tent of Meeting.
33.12: One day Moses said to the LORD, “You have been telling me, ‘Take these people up to the Promised Land.’ But you haven’t told me whom you will send with me. You have told me, ‘I know you by name, and I look favorably on you.’
33.13: If it is true that you look favorably on me, let me know your ways so I may understand you more fully and continue to enjoy your favor. And remember that this nation is your very own people.”
33.14: The LORD replied, “I will personally go with you, Moses, and I will give you rest—everything will be fine for you.”
33.15: Then Moses said, “If you don’t personally go with us, don’t make us leave this place.
33.16: How will anyone know that you look favorably on me—on me and on your people—if you don’t go with us? For your presence among us sets your people and me apart from all other people on the earth.”
33.17: The LORD replied to Moses, “I will indeed do what you have asked, for I look favorably on you, and I know you by name.”
33.18: Moses responded, “Then show me your glorious presence.”
33.19: The LORD replied, “I will make all my goodness pass before you, and I will call out my name, Yahweh, before you. For I will show mercy to anyone I choose, and I will show compassion to anyone I choose.
33.20: But you may not look directly at my face, for no one may see me and live.”
33.21: The LORD continued, “Look, stand near me on this rock.
33.22: As my glorious presence passes by, I will hide you in the crevice of the rock and cover you with my hand until I have passed by.
33.23: Then I will remove my hand and let you see me from behind. But my face will not be seen.”

34.1: Then the LORD told Moses, “Chisel out two stone tablets like the first ones. I will write on them the same words that were on the tablets you smashed.
34.2: Be ready in the morning to climb up Mount Sinai and present yourself to me on the top of the mountain.
34.3: No one else may come with you. In fact, no one is to appear anywhere on the mountain. Do not even let the flocks or herds graze near the mountain.”
34.4: So Moses chiseled out two tablets of stone like the first ones. Early in the morning he climbed Mount Sinai as the LORD had commanded him, and he carried the two stone tablets in his hands.
34.5: Then the LORD came down in a cloud and stood there with him; and he called out his own name, Yahweh.
34.6: The LORD passed in front of Moses, calling out, “Yahweh! The LORD! The God of compassion and mercy! I am slow to anger and filled with unfailing love and faithfulness.
34.7: I lavish unfailing love to a thousand generations. I forgive iniquity, rebellion, and sin. But I do not excuse the guilty. I lay the sins of the parents upon their children and grandchildren; the entire family is affected— even children in the third and fourth generations.”
34.8: Moses immediately threw himself to the ground and worshiped.
34.9: And he said, “O Lord, if it is true that I have found favor with you, then please travel with us. Yes, this is a stubborn and rebellious people, but please forgive our iniquity and our sins. Claim us as your own special possession.”
34.10: The LORD replied, “Listen, I am making a covenant with you in the presence of all your people. I will perform miracles that have never been performed anywhere in all the earth or in any nation. And all the people around you will see the power of the LORD—the awesome power I will display for you.
34.11: But listen carefully to everything I command you today. Then I will go ahead of you and drive out the Amorites, Canaanites, Hittites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites.
34.12: “Be very careful never to make a treaty with the people who live in the land where you are going. If you do, you will follow their evil ways and be trapped.
34.13: Instead, you must break down their pagan altars, smash their sacred pillars, and cut down their Asherah poles.
34.14: You must worship no other gods, for the LORD, whose very name is Jealous, is a God who is jealous about his relationship with you.
34.15: “You must not make a treaty of any kind with the people living in the land. They lust after their gods, offering sacrifices to them. They will invite you to join them in their sacrificial meals, and you will go with them.
34.16: Then you will accept their daughters, who sacrifice to other gods, as wives for your sons. And they will seduce your sons to commit adultery against me by worshiping other gods.
34.17: You must not make any gods of molten metal for yourselves.
34.18: “You must celebrate the Festival of Unleavened Bread. For seven days the bread you eat must be made without yeast, just as I commanded you. Celebrate this festival annually at the appointed time in early spring, in the month of Abib, for that is the anniversary of your departure from Egypt.
34.19: “The firstborn of every animal belongs to me, including the firstborn males from your herds of cattle and your flocks of sheep and goats.
34.20: A firstborn donkey may be bought back from the LORD by presenting a lamb or young goat in its place. But if you do not buy it back, you must break its neck. However, you must buy back every firstborn son. “No one may appear before me without an offering.
34.21: “You have six days each week for your ordinary work, but on the seventh day you must stop working, even during the seasons of plowing and harvest.
34.22: “You must celebrate the Festival of Harvest with the first crop of the wheat harvest, and celebrate the Festival of the Final Harvest at the end of the harvest season.
34.23: Three times each year every man in Israel must appear before the Sovereign, the LORD, the God of Israel.
34.24: I will drive out the other nations ahead of you and expand your territory, so no one will covet and conquer your land while you appear before the LORD your God three times each year.
34.25: “You must not offer the blood of my sacrificial offerings together with any baked goods containing yeast. And none of the meat of the Passover sacrifice may be kept over until the next morning.
34.26: “As you harvest your crops, bring the very best of the first harvest to the house of the LORD your God. “You must not cook a young goat in its mother’s milk.”
34.27: Then the LORD said to Moses, “Write down all these instructions, for they represent the terms of the covenant I am making with you and with Israel.”
34.28: Moses remained there on the mountain with the LORD forty days and forty nights. In all that time he ate no bread and drank no water. And the LORD wrote the terms of the covenant—the Ten Commandments—on the stone tablets.
34.29: When Moses came down Mount Sinai carrying the two stone tablets inscribed with the terms of the covenant, he wasn’t aware that his face had become radiant because he had spoken to the LORD.
34.30: So when Aaron and the people of Israel saw the radiance of Moses’ face, they were afraid to come near him.
34.31: But Moses called out to them and asked Aaron and all the leaders of the community to come over, and he talked with them.
34.32: Then all the people of Israel approached him, and Moses gave them all the instructions the LORD had given him on Mount Sinai.
34.33: When Moses finished speaking with them, he covered his face with a veil.
34.34: But whenever he went into the Tent of Meeting to speak with the LORD, he would remove the veil until he came out again. Then he would give the people whatever instructions the LORD had given him,
34.35: and the people of Israel would see the radiant glow of his face. So he would put the veil over his face until he returned to speak with the LORD.

35.1: Then Moses called together the whole community of Israel and told them, “These are the instructions the LORD has commanded you to follow.
35.2: You have six days each week for your ordinary work, but the seventh day must be a Sabbath day of complete rest, a holy day dedicated to the LORD. Anyone who works on that day must be put to death.
35.3: You must not even light a fire in any of your homes on the Sabbath.”
35.4: Then Moses said to the whole community of Israel, “This is what the LORD has commanded:
35.5: Take a sacred offering for the LORD. Let those with generous hearts present the following gifts to the LORD: gold, silver, and bronze;
35.6: blue, purple, and scarlet thread; fine linen and goat hair for cloth;
35.7: tanned ram skins and fine goatskin leather; acacia wood;
35.8: olive oil for the lamps; spices for the anointing oil and the fragrant incense;
35.9: onyx stones, and other gemstones to be set in the ephod and the priest’s chestpiece.
35.10: “Come, all of you who are gifted craftsmen. Construct everything that the LORD has commanded:
35.11: the Tabernacle and its sacred tent, its covering, clasps, frames, crossbars, posts, and bases;
35.12: the Ark and its carrying poles; the Ark’s cover—the place of atonement; the inner curtain to shield the Ark;
35.13: the table, its carrying poles, and all its utensils; the Bread of the Presence;
35.14: for light, the lampstand, its accessories, the lamp cups, and the olive oil for lighting;
35.15: the incense altar and its carrying poles; the anointing oil and fragrant incense; the curtain for the entrance of the Tabernacle;
35.16: the altar of burnt offering; the bronze grating of the altar and its carrying poles and utensils; the washbasin with its stand;
35.17: the curtains for the walls of the courtyard; the posts and their bases; the curtain for the entrance to the courtyard;
35.18: the tent pegs of the Tabernacle and courtyard and their ropes;
35.19: the beautifully stitched garments for the priests to wear while ministering in the Holy Place—the sacred garments for Aaron the priest, and the garments for his sons to wear as they minister as priests.”
35.20: So the whole community of Israel left Moses and returned to their tents.
35.21: All whose hearts were stirred and whose spirits were moved came and brought their sacred offerings to the LORD. They brought all the materials needed for the Tabernacle, for the performance of its rituals, and for the sacred garments.
35.22: Both men and women came, all whose hearts were willing. They brought to the LORD their offerings of gold—brooches, earrings, rings from their fingers, and necklaces. They presented gold objects of every kind as a special offering to the LORD.
35.23: All those who owned the following items willingly brought them: blue, purple, and scarlet thread; fine linen and goat hair for cloth; and tanned ram skins and fine goatskin leather.
35.24: And all who had silver and bronze objects gave them as a sacred offering to the LORD. And those who had acacia wood brought it for use in the project.
35.25: All the women who were skilled in sewing and spinning prepared blue, purple, and scarlet thread, and fine linen cloth.
35.26: All the women who were willing used their skills to spin the goat hair into yarn.
35.27: The leaders brought onyx stones and the special gemstones to be set in the ephod and the priest’s chestpiece.
35.28: They also brought spices and olive oil for the light, the anointing oil, and the fragrant incense.
35.29: So the people of Israel—every man and woman who was eager to help in the work the LORD had given them through Moses—brought their gifts and gave them freely to the LORD.
35.30: Then Moses told the people of Israel, “The LORD has specifically chosen Bezalel son of Uri, grandson of Hur, of the tribe of Judah.
35.31: The LORD has filled Bezalel with the Spirit of God, giving him great wisdom, ability, and expertise in all kinds of crafts.
35.32: He is a master craftsman, expert in working with gold, silver, and bronze.
35.33: He is skilled in engraving and mounting gemstones and in carving wood. He is a master at every craft.
35.34: And the LORD has given both him and Oholiab son of Ahisamach, of the tribe of Dan, the ability to teach their skills to others.
35.35: The LORD has given them special skills as engravers, designers, embroiderers in blue, purple, and scarlet thread on fine linen cloth, and weavers. They excel as craftsmen and as designers.

36.1: “The LORD has gifted Bezalel, Oholiab, and the other skilled craftsmen with wisdom and ability to perform any task involved in building the sanctuary. Let them construct and furnish the Tabernacle, just as the LORD has commanded.”
36.2: So Moses summoned Bezalel and Oholiab and all the others who were specially gifted by the LORD and were eager to get to work.
36.3: Moses gave them the materials donated by the people of Israel as sacred offerings for the completion of the sanctuary. But the people continued to bring additional gifts each morning.
36.4: Finally the craftsmen who were working on the sanctuary left their work.
36.5: They went to Moses and reported, “The people have given more than enough materials to complete the job the LORD has commanded us to do!”
36.6: So Moses gave the command, and this message was sent throughout the camp: “Men and women, don’t prepare any more gifts for the sanctuary. We have enough!” So the people stopped bringing their sacred offerings.
36.7: Their contributions were more than enough to complete the whole project.
36.8: The skilled craftsmen made ten curtains of finely woven linen for the Tabernacle. Then Bezalel decorated the curtains with blue, purple, and scarlet thread and with skillfully embroidered cherubim.
36.9: All ten curtains were exactly the same size—42 feet long and 6 feet wide.
36.10: Five of these curtains were joined together to make one long curtain, and the other five were joined to make a second long curtain.
36.11: He made fifty loops of blue yarn and put them along the edge of the last curtain in each set.
36.12: The fifty loops along the edge of one curtain matched the fifty loops along the edge of the other curtain.
36.13: Then he made fifty gold clasps and fastened the long curtains together with the clasps. In this way, the Tabernacle was made of one continuous piece.
36.14: He made eleven curtains of goat-hair cloth to serve as a tent covering for the Tabernacle.
36.15: These eleven curtains were all exactly the same size—45 feet long and 6 feet wide.
36.16: Bezalel joined five of these curtains together to make one long curtain, and the other six were joined to make a second long curtain.
36.17: He made fifty loops for the edge of each large curtain.
36.18: He also made fifty bronze clasps to fasten the long curtains together. In this way, the tent covering was made of one continuous piece.
36.19: He completed the tent covering with a layer of tanned ram skins and a layer of fine goatskin leather.
36.20: For the framework of the Tabernacle, Bezalel constructed frames of acacia wood.
36.21: Each frame was 15 feet high and 27 inches wide,
36.22: with two pegs under each frame. All the frames were identical.
36.23: He made twenty of these frames to support the curtains on the south side of the Tabernacle.
36.24: He also made forty silver bases—two bases under each frame, with the pegs fitting securely into the bases.
36.25: For the north side of the Tabernacle, he made another twenty frames,
36.26: with their forty silver bases, two bases under each frame.
36.27: He made six frames for the rear—the west side of the Tabernacle—
36.28: along with two additional frames to reinforce the rear corners of the Tabernacle.
36.29: These corner frames were matched at the bottom and firmly attached at the top with a single ring, forming a single corner unit. Both of these corner units were made the same way.
36.30: So there were eight frames at the rear of the Tabernacle, set in sixteen silver bases—two bases under each frame.
36.31: Then he made crossbars of acacia wood to link the frames, five crossbars for the north side of the Tabernacle
36.32: and five for the south side. He also made five crossbars for the rear of the Tabernacle, which faced west.
36.33: He made the middle crossbar to attach halfway up the frames; it ran all the way from one end of the Tabernacle to the other.
36.34: He overlaid the frames with gold and made gold rings to hold the crossbars. Then he overlaid the crossbars with gold as well.
36.35: For the inside of the Tabernacle, Bezalel made a special curtain of finely woven linen. He decorated it with blue, purple, and scarlet thread and with skillfully embroidered cherubim.
36.36: For the curtain, he made four posts of acacia wood and four gold hooks. He overlaid the posts with gold and set them in four silver bases.
36.37: Then he made another curtain for the entrance to the sacred tent. He made it of finely woven linen and embroidered it with exquisite designs using blue, purple, and scarlet thread.
36.38: This curtain was hung on gold hooks attached to five posts. The posts with their decorated tops and hooks were overlaid with gold, and the five bases were cast from bronze.

37.1: Next Bezalel made the Ark of acacia wood—a sacred chest 45 inches long, 27 inches wide, and 27 inches high.
37.2: He overlaid it inside and outside with pure gold, and he ran a molding of gold all around it.
37.3: He cast four gold rings and attached them to its four feet, two rings on each side.
37.4: Then he made poles from acacia wood and overlaid them with gold.
37.5: He inserted the poles into the rings at the sides of the Ark to carry it.
37.6: Then he made the Ark’s cover—the place of atonement—from pure gold. It was 45 inches long and 27 inches wide.
37.7: He made two cherubim from hammered gold and placed them on the two ends of the atonement cover.
37.8: He molded the cherubim on each end of the atonement cover, making it all of one piece of gold.
37.9: The cherubim faced each other and looked down on the atonement cover. With their wings spread above it, they protected it.
37.10: Then Bezalel made the table of acacia wood, 36 inches long, 18 inches wide, and 27 inches high.
37.11: He overlaid it with pure gold and ran a gold molding around the edge.
37.12: He decorated it with a 3-inch border all around, and he ran a gold molding along the border.
37.13: Then he cast four gold rings for the table and attached them at the four corners next to the four legs.
37.14: The rings were attached near the border to hold the poles that were used to carry the table.
37.15: He made these poles from acacia wood and overlaid them with gold.
37.16: Then he made special containers of pure gold for the table—bowls, ladles, jars, and pitchers—to be used in pouring out liquid offerings.
37.17: Then Bezalel made the lampstand of pure, hammered gold. He made the entire lampstand and its decorations of one piece—the base, center stem, lamp cups, buds, and petals.
37.18: The lampstand had six branches going out from the center stem, three on each side.
37.19: Each of the six branches had three lamp cups shaped like almond blossoms, complete with buds and petals.
37.20: The center stem of the lampstand was crafted with four lamp cups shaped like almond blossoms, complete with buds and petals.
37.21: There was an almond bud beneath each pair of branches where the six branches extended from the center stem, all made of one piece.
37.22: The almond buds and branches were all of one piece with the center stem, and they were hammered from pure gold.
37.23: He also made seven lamps for the lampstand, lamp snuffers, and trays, all of pure gold.
37.24: The entire lampstand, along with its accessories, was made from 75 pounds of pure gold.
37.25: Then Bezalel made the incense altar of acacia wood. It was 18 inches square and 36 inches high, with horns at the corners carved from the same piece of wood as the altar itself.
37.26: He overlaid the top, sides, and horns of the altar with pure gold, and he ran a gold molding around the entire altar.
37.27: He made two gold rings and attached them on opposite sides of the altar below the gold molding to hold the carrying poles.
37.28: He made the poles of acacia wood and overlaid them with gold.
37.29: Then he made the sacred anointing oil and the fragrant incense, using the techniques of a skilled incense maker.

38.1: Next Bezalel used acacia wood to construct the square altar of burnt offering. It was 7 1 / 2 feet wide, 7 1 / 2 feet long, and 4 1 / 2 feet high.
38.2: He made horns for each of its four corners so that the horns and altar were all one piece. He overlaid the altar with bronze.
38.3: Then he made all the altar utensils of bronze—the ash buckets, shovels, basins, meat forks, and firepans.
38.4: Next he made a bronze grating and installed it halfway down the side of the altar, under the ledge.
38.5: He cast four rings and attached them to the corners of the bronze grating to hold the carrying poles.
38.6: He made the poles from acacia wood and overlaid them with bronze.
38.7: He inserted the poles through the rings on the sides of the altar. The altar was hollow and was made from planks.
38.8: Bezalel made the bronze washbasin and its bronze stand from bronze mirrors donated by the women who served at the entrance of the Tabernacle.
38.9: Then Bezalel made the courtyard, which was enclosed with curtains made of finely woven linen. On the south side the curtains were 150 feet long.
38.10: They were held up by twenty posts set securely in twenty bronze bases. He hung the curtains with silver hooks and rings.
38.11: He made a similar set of curtains for the north side—150 feet of curtains held up by twenty posts set securely in bronze bases. He hung the curtains with silver hooks and rings.
38.12: The curtains on the west end of the courtyard were 75 feet long, hung with silver hooks and rings and supported by ten posts set into ten bases.
38.13: The east end, the front, was also 75 feet long.
38.14: The courtyard entrance was on the east end, flanked by two curtains. The curtain on the right side was 22 1 / 2 feet long and was supported by three posts set into three bases.
38.15: The curtain on the left side was also 22 1 / 2 feet long and was supported by three posts set into three bases.
38.16: All the curtains used in the courtyard were made of finely woven linen.
38.17: Each post had a bronze base, and all the hooks and rings were silver. The tops of the posts of the courtyard were overlaid with silver, and the rings to hold up the curtains were made of silver.
38.18: He made the curtain for the entrance to the courtyard of finely woven linen, and he decorated it with beautiful embroidery in blue, purple, and scarlet thread. It was 30 feet long, and its height was 7 1 / 2 feet, just like the curtains of the courtyard walls.
38.19: It was supported by four posts, each set securely in its own bronze base. The tops of the posts were overlaid with silver, and the hooks and rings were also made of silver.
38.20: All the tent pegs used in the Tabernacle and courtyard were made of bronze.
38.21: This is an inventory of the materials used in building the Tabernacle of the Covenant. The Levites compiled the figures, as Moses directed, and Ithamar son of Aaron the priest served as recorder.
38.22: Bezalel son of Uri, grandson of Hur, of the tribe of Judah, made everything just as the LORD had commanded Moses.
38.23: He was assisted by Oholiab son of Ahisamach, of the tribe of Dan, a craftsman expert at engraving, designing, and embroidering with blue, purple, and scarlet thread on fine linen cloth.
38.24: The people brought special offerings of gold totaling 2,193 pounds, as measured by the weight of the sanctuary shekel. This gold was used throughout the Tabernacle.
38.25: The whole community of Israel gave 7,545 pounds of silver, as measured by the weight of the sanctuary shekel.
38.26: This silver came from the tax collected from each man registered in the census. (The tax is one beka, which is half a shekel, based on the sanctuary shekel.) The tax was collected from 603,550 men who had reached their twentieth birthday.
38.27: The hundred bases for the frames of the sanctuary walls and for the posts supporting the inner curtain required 7,500 pounds of silver, about 75 pounds for each base.
38.28: The remaining 45 pounds of silver was used to make the hooks and rings and to overlay the tops of the posts.
38.29: The people also brought as special offerings 5,310 pounds of bronze,
38.30: which was used for casting the bases for the posts at the entrance to the Tabernacle, and for the bronze altar with its bronze grating and all the altar utensils.
38.31: Bronze was also used to make the bases for the posts that supported the curtains around the courtyard, the bases for the curtain at the entrance of the courtyard, and all the tent pegs for the Tabernacle and the courtyard.

39.1: The craftsmen made beautiful sacred garments of blue, purple, and scarlet cloth—clothing for Aaron to wear while ministering in the Holy Place, just as the LORD had commanded Moses.
39.2: Bezalel made the ephod of finely woven linen and embroidered it with gold and with blue, purple, and scarlet thread.
39.3: He made gold thread by hammering out thin sheets of gold and cutting it into fine strands. With great skill and care, he worked it into the fine linen with the blue, purple, and scarlet thread.
39.4: The ephod consisted of two pieces, front and back, joined at the shoulders with two shoulder-pieces.
39.5: The decorative sash was made of the same materials: finely woven linen embroidered with gold and with blue, purple, and scarlet thread, just as the LORD had commanded Moses.
39.6: They mounted the two onyx stones in settings of gold filigree. The stones were engraved with the names of the tribes of Israel, just as a seal is engraved.
39.7: He fastened these stones on the shoulder-pieces of the ephod as a reminder that the priest represents the people of Israel. All this was done just as the LORD had commanded Moses.
39.8: Bezalel made the chestpiece with great skill and care. He made it to match the ephod, using finely woven linen embroidered with gold and with blue, purple, and scarlet thread.
39.9: He made the chestpiece of a single piece of cloth folded to form a pouch nine inches square.
39.10: They mounted four rows of gemstones on it. The first row contained a red carnelian, a pale-green peridot, and an emerald.
39.11: The second row contained a turquoise, a blue lapis lazuli, and a white moonstone.
39.12: The third row contained an orange jacinth, an agate, and a purple amethyst.
39.13: The fourth row contained a blue-green beryl, an onyx, and a green jasper. All these stones were set in gold filigree.
39.14: Each stone represented one of the twelve sons of Israel, and the name of that tribe was engraved on it like a seal.
39.15: To attach the chestpiece to the ephod, they made braided cords of pure gold thread.
39.16: They also made two settings of gold filigree and two gold rings and attached them to the top corners of the chestpiece.
39.17: They tied the two gold cords to the rings on the chestpiece.
39.18: They tied the other ends of the cords to the gold settings on the shoulder-pieces of the ephod.
39.19: Then they made two more gold rings and attached them to the inside edges of the chestpiece next to the ephod.
39.20: Then they made two more gold rings and attached them to the front of the ephod, below the shoulder-pieces, just above the knot where the decorative sash was fastened to the ephod.
39.21: They attached the bottom rings of the chestpiece to the rings on the ephod with blue cords. In this way, the chestpiece was held securely to the ephod above the decorative sash. All this was done just as the LORD had commanded Moses.
39.22: Bezalel made the robe that is worn with the ephod from a single piece of blue woven cloth,
39.23: with an opening for Aaron’s head in the middle of it. The opening was reinforced with a woven collar so it would not tear.
39.24: They made pomegranates of blue, purple, and scarlet yarn, and attached them to the hem of the robe.
39.25: They also made bells of pure gold and placed them between the pomegranates along the hem of the robe,
39.26: with bells and pomegranates alternating all around the hem. This robe was to be worn whenever the priest ministered before the LORD, just as the LORD had commanded Moses.
39.27: They made tunics for Aaron and his sons from fine linen cloth.
39.28: The turban and the special head coverings were made of fine linen, and the undergarments were also made of finely woven linen.
39.29: The sashes were made of finely woven linen and embroidered with blue, purple, and scarlet thread, just as the LORD had commanded Moses.
39.30: Finally, they made the sacred medallion—the badge of holiness—of pure gold. They engraved it like a seal with these words: Holy to the Lord .
39.31: They attached the medallion with a blue cord to Aaron’s turban, just as the LORD had commanded Moses.
39.32: And so at last the Tabernacle was finished. The Israelites had done everything just as the LORD had commanded Moses.
39.33: And they brought the entire Tabernacle to Moses: the sacred tent with all its furnishings, clasps, frames, crossbars, posts, and bases;
39.34: the tent coverings of tanned ram skins and fine goatskin leather; the inner curtain to shield the Ark;
39.35: the Ark of the Covenant and its carrying poles; the Ark’s cover—the place of atonement;
39.36: the table and all its utensils; the Bread of the Presence;
39.37: the pure gold lampstand with its symmetrical lamp cups, all its accessories, and the olive oil for lighting;
39.38: the gold altar; the anointing oil and fragrant incense; the curtain for the entrance of the sacred tent;
39.39: the bronze altar; the bronze grating and its carrying poles and utensils; the washbasin with its stand;
39.40: the curtains for the walls of the courtyard; the posts and their bases; the curtain for the entrance to the courtyard; the ropes and tent pegs; all the furnishings to be used in worship at the Tabernacle;
39.41: the beautifully stitched garments for the priests to wear while ministering in the Holy Place—the sacred garments for Aaron the priest, and the garments for his sons to wear as they minister as priests.
39.42: So the people of Israel followed all of the LORD’s instructions to Moses.
39.43: Then Moses inspected all their work. When he found it had been done just as the LORD had commanded him, he blessed them.

40.1: Then the LORD said to Moses,
40.2: “Set up the Tabernacle on the first day of the new year.
40.3: Place the Ark of the Covenant inside, and install the inner curtain to enclose the Ark within the Most Holy Place.
40.4: Then bring in the table, and arrange the utensils on it. And bring in the lampstand, and set up the lamps.
40.5: “Place the gold incense altar in front of the Ark of the Covenant. Then hang the curtain at the entrance of the Tabernacle.
40.6: Place the altar of burnt offering in front of the Tabernacle entrance.
40.7: Set the washbasin between the Tabernacle and the altar, and fill it with water.
40.8: Then set up the courtyard around the outside of the tent, and hang the curtain for the courtyard entrance.
40.9: “Take the anointing oil and anoint the Tabernacle and all its furnishings to consecrate them and make them holy.
40.10: Anoint the altar of burnt offering and its utensils to consecrate them. Then the altar will become absolutely holy.
40.11: Next anoint the washbasin and its stand to consecrate them.
40.12: “Present Aaron and his sons at the entrance of the Tabernacle, and wash them with water.
40.13: Dress Aaron with the sacred garments and anoint him, consecrating him to serve me as a priest.
40.14: Then present his sons and dress them in their tunics.
40.15: Anoint them as you did their father, so they may also serve me as priests. With their anointing, Aaron’s descendants are set apart for the priesthood forever, from generation to generation.”
40.16: Moses proceeded to do everything just as the LORD had commanded him.
40.17: So the Tabernacle was set up on the first day of the first month of the second year.
40.18: Moses erected the Tabernacle by setting down its bases, inserting the frames, attaching the crossbars, and setting up the posts.
40.19: Then he spread the coverings over the Tabernacle framework and put on the protective layers, just as the LORD had commanded him.
40.20: He took the stone tablets inscribed with the terms of the covenant and placed them inside the Ark. Then he attached the carrying poles to the Ark, and he set the Ark’s cover—the place of atonement—on top of it.
40.21: Then he brought the Ark of the Covenant into the Tabernacle and hung the inner curtain to shield it from view, just as the LORD had commanded him.
40.22: Next Moses placed the table in the Tabernacle, along the north side of the Holy Place, just outside the inner curtain.
40.23: And he arranged the Bread of the Presence on the table before the LORD, just as the LORD had commanded him.
40.24: He set the lampstand in the Tabernacle across from the table on the south side of the Holy Place.
40.25: Then he lit the lamps in the LORD’s presence, just as the LORD had commanded him.
40.26: He also placed the gold incense altar in the Tabernacle, in the Holy Place in front of the inner curtain.
40.27: On it he burned the fragrant incense, just as the LORD had commanded him.
40.28: He hung the curtain at the entrance of the Tabernacle,
40.29: and he placed the altar of burnt offering near the Tabernacle entrance. On it he offered a burnt offering and a grain offering, just as the LORD had commanded him.
40.30: Next Moses placed the washbasin between the Tabernacle and the altar. He filled it with water so the priests could wash themselves.
40.31: Moses and Aaron and Aaron’s sons used water from it to wash their hands and feet.
40.32: Whenever they approached the altar and entered the Tabernacle, they washed themselves, just as the LORD had commanded Moses.
40.33: Then he hung the curtains forming the courtyard around the Tabernacle and the altar. And he set up the curtain at the entrance of the courtyard. So at last Moses finished the work.
40.34: Then the cloud covered the Tabernacle, and the glory of the LORD filled the Tabernacle.
40.35: Moses could no longer enter the Tabernacle because the cloud had settled down over it, and the glory of the LORD filled the Tabernacle.
40.36: Now whenever the cloud lifted from the Tabernacle, the people of Israel would set out on their journey, following it.
40.37: But if the cloud did not rise, they remained where they were until it lifted.
40.38: The cloud of the LORD hovered over the Tabernacle during the day, and at night fire glowed inside the cloud so the whole family of Israel could see it. This continued throughout all their journeys.

1.1: The LORD called to Moses from the Tabernacle and said to him,
1.2: “Give the following instructions to the people of Israel. When you present an animal as an offering to the LORD, you may take it from your herd of cattle or your flock of sheep and goats.
1.3: “If the animal you present as a burnt offering is from the herd, it must be a male with no defects. Bring it to the entrance of the Tabernacle so you may be accepted by the LORD.
1.4: Lay your hand on the animal’s head, and the LORD will accept its death in your place to purify you, making you right with him.
1.5: Then slaughter the young bull in the LORD’s presence, and Aaron’s sons, the priests, will present the animal’s blood by splattering it against all sides of the altar that stands at the entrance to the Tabernacle.
1.6: Then skin the animal and cut it into pieces.
1.7: The sons of Aaron the priest will build a wood fire on the altar.
1.8: They will arrange the pieces of the offering, including the head and fat, on the wood burning on the altar.
1.9: But the internal organs and the legs must first be washed with water. Then the priest will burn the entire sacrifice on the altar as a burnt offering. It is a special gift, a pleasing aroma to the LORD.
1.10: “If the animal you present as a burnt offering is from the flock, it may be either a sheep or a goat, but it must be a male with no defects.
1.11: Slaughter the animal on the north side of the altar in the LORD’s presence, and Aaron’s sons, the priests, will splatter its blood against all sides of the altar.
1.12: Then cut the animal in pieces, and the priests will arrange the pieces of the offering, including the head and fat, on the wood burning on the altar.
1.13: But the internal organs and the legs must first be washed with water. Then the priest will burn the entire sacrifice on the altar as a burnt offering. It is a special gift, a pleasing aroma to the LORD.
1.14: “If you present a bird as a burnt offering to the LORD, choose either a turtledove or a young pigeon.
1.15: The priest will take the bird to the altar, wring off its head, and burn it on the altar. But first he must drain its blood against the side of the altar.
1.16: The priest must also remove the crop and the feathers and throw them in the ashes on the east side of the altar.
1.17: Then, grasping the bird by its wings, the priest will tear the bird open, but without tearing it apart. Then he will burn it as a burnt offering on the wood burning on the altar. It is a special gift, a pleasing aroma to the LORD.

2.1: “When you present grain as an offering to the LORD, the offering must consist of choice flour. You are to pour olive oil on it, sprinkle it with frankincense,
2.2: and bring it to Aaron’s sons, the priests. The priest will scoop out a handful of the flour moistened with oil, together with all the frankincense, and burn this representative portion on the altar. It is a special gift, a pleasing aroma to the LORD.
2.3: The rest of the grain offering will then be given to Aaron and his sons. This offering will be considered a most holy part of the special gifts presented to the LORD.
2.4: “If your offering is a grain offering baked in an oven, it must be made of choice flour, but without any yeast. It may be presented in the form of thin cakes mixed with olive oil or wafers spread with olive oil.
2.5: If your grain offering is cooked on a griddle, it must be made of choice flour mixed with olive oil but without any yeast.
2.6: Break it in pieces and pour olive oil on it; it is a grain offering.
2.7: If your grain offering is prepared in a pan, it must be made of choice flour and olive oil.
2.8: “No matter how a grain offering for the LORD has been prepared, bring it to the priest, who will present it at the altar.
2.9: The priest will take a representative portion of the grain offering and burn it on the altar. It is a special gift, a pleasing aroma to the LORD.
2.10: The rest of the grain offering will then be given to Aaron and his sons as their food. This offering will be considered a most holy part of the special gifts presented to the LORD.
2.11: “Do not use yeast in preparing any of the grain offerings you present to the LORD, because no yeast or honey may be burned as a special gift presented to the LORD.
2.12: You may add yeast and honey to an offering of the first crops of your harvest, but these must never be offered on the altar as a pleasing aroma to the LORD.
2.13: Season all your grain offerings with salt to remind you of God’s eternal covenant. Never forget to add salt to your grain offerings.
2.14: “If you present a grain offering to the LORD from the first portion of your harvest, bring fresh grain that is coarsely ground and roasted on a fire.
2.15: Put olive oil on this grain offering, and sprinkle it with frankincense.
2.16: The priest will take a representative portion of the grain moistened with oil, together with all the frankincense, and burn it as a special gift presented to the LORD.

3.1: “If you present an animal from the herd as a peace offering to the LORD, it may be a male or a female, but it must have no defects.
3.2: Lay your hand on the animal’s head, and slaughter it at the entrance of the Tabernacle. Then Aaron’s sons, the priests, will splatter its blood against all sides of the altar.
3.3: The priest must present part of this peace offering as a special gift to the LORD. This includes all the fat around the internal organs,
3.4: the two kidneys and the fat around them near the loins, and the long lobe of the liver. These must be removed with the kidneys,
3.5: and Aaron’s sons will burn them on top of the burnt offering on the wood burning on the altar. It is a special gift, a pleasing aroma to the LORD.
3.6: “If you present an animal from the flock as a peace offering to the LORD, it may be a male or a female, but it must have no defects.
3.7: If you present a sheep as your offering, bring it to the LORD,
3.8: lay your hand on its head, and slaughter it in front of the Tabernacle. Aaron’s sons will then splatter the sheep’s blood against all sides of the altar.
3.9: The priest must present the fat of this peace offering as a special gift to the LORD. This includes the fat of the broad tail cut off near the backbone, all the fat around the internal organs,
3.10: the two kidneys and the fat around them near the loins, and the long lobe of the liver. These must be removed with the kidneys,
3.11: and the priest will burn them on the altar. It is a special gift of food presented to the LORD.
3.12: “If you present a goat as your offering, bring it to the LORD,
3.13: lay your hand on its head, and slaughter it in front of the Tabernacle. Aaron’s sons will then splatter the goat’s blood against all sides of the altar.
3.14: The priest must present part of this offering as a special gift to the LORD. This includes all the fat around the internal organs,
3.15: the two kidneys and the fat around them near the loins, and the long lobe of the liver. These must be removed with the kidneys,
3.16: and the priest will burn them on the altar. It is a special gift of food, a pleasing aroma to the LORD. All the fat belongs to the LORD.
3.17: “You must never eat any fat or blood. This is a permanent law for you, and it must be observed from generation to generation, wherever you live.”

4.1: Then the LORD said to Moses,
4.2: “Give the following instructions to the people of Israel. This is how you are to deal with those who sin unintentionally by doing anything that violates one of the LORD’s commands.
4.3: “If the high priest sins, bringing guilt upon the entire community, he must give a sin offering for the sin he has committed. He must present to the LORD a young bull with no defects.
4.4: He must bring the bull to the LORD at the entrance of the Tabernacle, lay his hand on the bull’s head, and slaughter it before the LORD.
4.5: The high priest will then take some of the bull’s blood into the Tabernacle,
4.6: dip his finger in the blood, and sprinkle it seven times before the LORD in front of the inner curtain of the sanctuary.
4.7: The priest will then put some of the blood on the horns of the altar for fragrant incense that stands in the LORD’s presence inside the Tabernacle. He will pour out the rest of the bull’s blood at the base of the altar for burnt offerings at the entrance of the Tabernacle.
4.8: Then the priest must remove all the fat of the bull to be offered as a sin offering. This includes all the fat around the internal organs,
4.9: the two kidneys and the fat around them near the loins, and the long lobe of the liver. He must remove these along with the kidneys,
4.10: just as he does with cattle offered as a peace offering, and burn them on the altar of burnt offerings.
4.11: But he must take whatever is left of the bull—its hide, meat, head, legs, internal organs, and dung—
4.12: and carry it away to a place outside the camp that is ceremonially clean, the place where the ashes are dumped. There, on the ash heap, he will burn it on a wood fire.
4.13: “If the entire Israelite community sins by violating one of the LORD’s commands, but the people don’t realize it, they are still guilty.
4.14: When they become aware of their sin, the people must bring a young bull as an offering for their sin and present it before the Tabernacle.
4.15: The elders of the community must then lay their hands on the bull’s head and slaughter it before the LORD.
4.16: The high priest will then take some of the bull’s blood into the Tabernacle,
4.17: dip his finger in the blood, and sprinkle it seven times before the LORD in front of the inner curtain.
4.18: He will then put some of the blood on the horns of the altar for fragrant incense that stands in the LORD’s presence inside the Tabernacle. He will pour out the rest of the blood at the base of the altar for burnt offerings at the entrance of the Tabernacle.
4.19: Then the priest must remove all the animal’s fat and burn it on the altar,
4.20: just as he does with the bull offered as a sin offering for the high priest. Through this process, the priest will purify the people, making them right with the LORD, and they will be forgiven.
4.21: Then the priest must take what is left of the bull and carry it outside the camp and burn it there, just as is done with the sin offering for the high priest. This offering is for the sin of the entire congregation of Israel.
4.22: “If one of Israel’s leaders sins by violating one of the commands of the LORD his God but doesn’t realize it, he is still guilty.
4.23: When he becomes aware of his sin, he must bring as his offering a male goat with no defects.
4.24: He must lay his hand on the goat’s head and slaughter it at the place where burnt offerings are slaughtered before the LORD. This is an offering for his sin.
4.25: Then the priest will dip his finger in the blood of the sin offering and put it on the horns of the altar for burnt offerings. He will pour out the rest of the blood at the base of the altar.
4.26: Then he must burn all the goat’s fat on the altar, just as he does with the peace offering. Through this process, the priest will purify the leader from his sin, making him right with the LORD, and he will be forgiven.
4.27: “If any of the common people sin by violating one of the LORD’s commands, but they don’t realize it, they are still guilty.
4.28: When they become aware of their sin, they must bring as an offering for their sin a female goat with no defects.
4.29: They must lay a hand on the head of the sin offering and slaughter it at the place where burnt offerings are slaughtered.
4.30: Then the priest will dip his finger in the blood and put it on the horns of the altar for burnt offerings. He will pour out the rest of the blood at the base of the altar.
4.31: Then he must remove all the goat’s fat, just as he does with the fat of the peace offering. He will burn the fat on the altar, and it will be a pleasing aroma to the LORD. Through this process, the priest will purify the people, making them right with the LORD, and they will be forgiven.
4.32: “If the people bring a sheep as their sin offering, it must be a female with no defects.
4.33: They must lay a hand on the head of the sin offering and slaughter it at the place where burnt offerings are slaughtered.
4.34: Then the priest will dip his finger in the blood of the sin offering and put it on the horns of the altar for burnt offerings. He will pour out the rest of the blood at the base of the altar.
4.35: Then he must remove all the sheep’s fat, just as he does with the fat of a sheep presented as a peace offering. He will burn the fat on the altar on top of the special gifts presented to the LORD. Through this process, the priest will purify the people from their sin, making them right with the LORD, and they will be forgiven.

5.1: “If you are called to testify about something you have seen or that you know about, it is sinful to refuse to testify, and you will be punished for your sin.
5.2: “Or suppose you unknowingly touch something that is ceremonially unclean, such as the carcass of an unclean animal. When you realize what you have done, you must admit your defilement and your guilt. This is true whether it is a wild animal, a domestic animal, or an animal that scurries along the ground.
5.3: “Or suppose you unknowingly touch something that makes a person unclean. When you realize what you have done, you must admit your guilt.
5.4: “Or suppose you make a foolish vow of any kind, whether its purpose is for good or for bad. When you realize its foolishness, you must admit your guilt.
5.5: “When you become aware of your guilt in any of these ways, you must confess your sin.
5.6: Then you must bring to the LORD as the penalty for your sin a female from the flock, either a sheep or a goat. This is a sin offering with which the priest will purify you from your sin, making you right with the LORD.
5.7: “But if you cannot afford to bring a sheep, you may bring to the LORD two turtledoves or two young pigeons as the penalty for your sin. One of the birds will be for a sin offering, and the other for a burnt offering.
5.8: You must bring them to the priest, who will present the first bird as the sin offering. He will wring its neck but without severing its head from the body.
5.9: Then he will sprinkle some of the blood of the sin offering against the sides of the altar, and the rest of the blood will be drained out at the base of the altar. This is an offering for sin.
5.10: The priest will then prepare the second bird as a burnt offering, following all the procedures that have been prescribed. Through this process the priest will purify you from your sin, making you right with the LORD, and you will be forgiven.
5.11: “If you cannot afford to bring two turtledoves or two young pigeons, you may bring two quarts of choice flour for your sin offering. Since it is an offering for sin, you must not moisten it with olive oil or put any frankincense on it.
5.12: Take the flour to the priest, who will scoop out a handful as a representative portion. He will burn it on the altar on top of the special gifts presented to the LORD. It is an offering for sin.
5.13: Through this process, the priest will purify those who are guilty of any of these sins, making them right with the LORD, and they will be forgiven. The rest of the flour will belong to the priest, just as with the grain offering.”
5.14: Then the LORD said to Moses,
5.15: “If one of you commits a sin by unintentionally defiling the LORD’s sacred property, you must bring a guilt offering to the LORD. The offering must be your own ram with no defects, or you may buy one of equal value with silver, as measured by the weight of the sanctuary shekel.
5.16: You must make restitution for the sacred property you have harmed by paying for the loss, plus an additional 20 percent. When you give the payment to the priest, he will purify you with the ram sacrificed as a guilt offering, making you right with the LORD, and you will be forgiven.
5.17: “Suppose you sin by violating one of the LORD’s commands. Even if you are unaware of what you have done, you are guilty and will be punished for your sin.
5.18: For a guilt offering, you must bring to the priest your own ram with no defects, or you may buy one of equal value. Through this process the priest will purify you from your unintentional sin, making you right with the LORD, and you will be forgiven.
5.19: This is a guilt offering, for you have been guilty of an offense against the LORD.”

6.1: Then the LORD said to Moses,
6.2: “Suppose one of you sins against your associate and is unfaithful to the LORD. Suppose you cheat in a deal involving a security deposit, or you steal or commit fraud,
6.3: or you find lost property and lie about it, or you lie while swearing to tell the truth, or you commit any other such sin.
6.4: If you have sinned in any of these ways, you are guilty. You must give back whatever you stole, or the money you took by extortion, or the security deposit, or the lost property you found,
6.5: or anything obtained by swearing falsely. You must make restitution by paying the full price plus an additional 20 percent to the person you have harmed. On the same day you must present a guilt offering.
6.6: As a guilt offering to the LORD, you must bring to the priest your own ram with no defects, or you may buy one of equal value.
6.7: Through this process, the priest will purify you before the LORD, making you right with him, and you will be forgiven for any of these sins you have committed.”
6.8: Then the LORD said to Moses,
6.9: “Give Aaron and his sons the following instructions regarding the burnt offering. The burnt offering must be left on top of the altar until the next morning, and the fire on the altar must be kept burning all night.
6.10: In the morning, after the priest on duty has put on his official linen clothing and linen undergarments, he must clean out the ashes of the burnt offering and put them beside the altar.
6.11: Then he must take off these garments, change back into his regular clothes, and carry the ashes outside the camp to a place that is ceremonially clean.
6.12: Meanwhile, the fire on the altar must be kept burning; it must never go out. Each morning the priest will add fresh wood to the fire and arrange the burnt offering on it. He will then burn the fat of the peace offerings on it.
6.13: Remember, the fire must be kept burning on the altar at all times. It must never go out.
6.14: “These are the instructions regarding the grain offering. Aaron’s sons must present this offering to the LORD in front of the altar.
6.15: The priest on duty will take from the grain offering a handful of the choice flour moistened with olive oil, together with all the frankincense. He will burn this representative portion on the altar as a pleasing aroma to the LORD.
6.16: Aaron and his sons may eat the rest of the flour, but it must be baked without yeast and eaten in a sacred place within the courtyard of the Tabernacle.
6.17: Remember, it must never be prepared with yeast. I have given it to the priests as their share of the special gifts presented to me. Like the sin offering and the guilt offering, it is most holy.
6.18: Any of Aaron’s male descendants may eat from the special gifts presented to the LORD. This is their permanent right from generation to generation. Anyone or anything that touches these offerings will become holy.”
6.19: Then the LORD said to Moses,
6.20: “On the day Aaron and his sons are anointed, they must present to the LORD the standard grain offering of two quarts of choice flour, half to be offered in the morning and half to be offered in the evening.
6.21: It must be carefully mixed with olive oil and cooked on a griddle. Then slice this grain offering and present it as a pleasing aroma to the LORD.
6.22: In each generation, the high priest who succeeds Aaron must prepare this same offering. It belongs to the LORD and must be burned up completely. This is a permanent law.
6.23: All such grain offerings of a priest must be burned up entirely. None of it may be eaten.”
6.24: Then the LORD said to Moses,
6.25: “Give Aaron and his sons the following instructions regarding the sin offering. The animal given as an offering for sin is a most holy offering, and it must be slaughtered in the LORD’s presence at the place where the burnt offerings are slaughtered.
6.26: The priest who offers the sacrifice as a sin offering must eat his portion in a sacred place within the courtyard of the Tabernacle.
6.27: Anyone or anything that touches the sacrificial meat will become holy. If any of the sacrificial blood spatters on a person’s clothing, the soiled garment must be washed in a sacred place.
6.28: If a clay pot is used to boil the sacrificial meat, it must then be broken. If a bronze pot is used, it must be scoured and thoroughly rinsed with water.
6.29: Any male from a priest’s family may eat from this offering; it is most holy.
6.30: But the offering for sin may not be eaten if its blood was brought into the Tabernacle as an offering for purification in the Holy Place. It must be completely burned with fire.

7.1: “These are the instructions for the guilt offering. It is most holy.
7.2: The animal sacrificed as a guilt offering must be slaughtered at the place where the burnt offerings are slaughtered, and its blood must be splattered against all sides of the altar.
7.3: The priest will then offer all its fat on the altar, including the fat of the broad tail, the fat around the internal organs,
7.4: the two kidneys and the fat around them near the loins, and the long lobe of the liver. These are to be removed with the kidneys,
7.5: and the priests will burn them on the altar as a special gift presented to the LORD. This is the guilt offering.
7.6: Any male from a priest’s family may eat the meat. It must be eaten in a sacred place, for it is most holy.
7.7: “The same instructions apply to both the guilt offering and the sin offering. Both belong to the priest who uses them to purify someone, making that person right with the LORD.
7.8: In the case of the burnt offering, the priest may keep the hide of the sacrificed animal.
7.9: Any grain offering that has been baked in an oven, prepared in a pan, or cooked on a griddle belongs to the priest who presents it.
7.10: All other grain offerings, whether made of dry flour or flour moistened with olive oil, are to be shared equally among all the priests, the descendants of Aaron.
7.11: “These are the instructions regarding the different kinds of peace offerings that may be presented to the LORD.
7.12: If you present your peace offering as an expression of thanksgiving, the usual animal sacrifice must be accompanied by various kinds of bread made without yeast—thin cakes mixed with olive oil, wafers spread with oil, and cakes made of choice flour mixed with olive oil.
7.13: This peace offering of thanksgiving must also be accompanied by loaves of bread made with yeast.
7.14: One of each kind of bread must be presented as a gift to the LORD. It will then belong to the priest who splatters the blood of the peace offering against the altar.
7.15: The meat of the peace offering of thanksgiving must be eaten on the same day it is offered. None of it may be saved for the next morning.
7.16: “If you bring an offering to fulfill a vow or as a voluntary offering, the meat must be eaten on the same day the sacrifice is offered, but whatever is left over may be eaten on the second day.
7.17: Any meat left over until the third day must be completely burned up.
7.18: If any of the meat from the peace offering is eaten on the third day, the person who presented it will not be accepted by the LORD. You will receive no credit for offering it. By then the meat will be contaminated; if you eat it, you will be punished for your sin.
7.19: “Meat that touches anything ceremonially unclean may not be eaten; it must be completely burned up. The rest of the meat may be eaten, but only by people who are ceremonially clean.
7.20: If you are ceremonially unclean and you eat meat from a peace offering that was presented to the LORD, you will be cut off from the community.
7.21: If you touch anything that is unclean (whether it is human defilement or an unclean animal or any other unclean, detestable thing) and then eat meat from a peace offering presented to the LORD, you will be cut off from the community.”
7.22: Then the LORD said to Moses,
7.23: “Give the following instructions to the people of Israel. You must never eat fat, whether from cattle, sheep, or goats.
7.24: The fat of an animal found dead or torn to pieces by wild animals must never be eaten, though it may be used for any other purpose.
7.25: Anyone who eats fat from an animal presented as a special gift to the LORD will be cut off from the community.
7.26: No matter where you live, you must never consume the blood of any bird or animal.
7.27: Anyone who consumes blood will be cut off from the community.”
7.28: Then the LORD said to Moses,
7.29: “Give the following instructions to the people of Israel. When you present a peace offering to the LORD, bring part of it as a gift to the LORD.
7.30: Present it to the LORD with your own hands as a special gift to the LORD. Bring the fat of the animal, together with the breast, and lift up the breast as a special offering to the LORD.
7.31: Then the priest will burn the fat on the altar, but the breast will belong to Aaron and his descendants.
